An episode about how to read a book. And what better way to cover the topic than to read a book about it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/42-how-to-read-a-book-by-mortimer-adler/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

Joe did NOT enjoy the redesign of a certain productivity app. The two share computer horror stories (though one of them has frustratingly never had any real problems), and Joe reveals a major new ‘experiment’.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/10-im-going-to-have-a-problem-tomorrow-because-im-saying-this-now/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/whimsthatworklogo.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

Joe has a theory on goal-setting. Joe thinks giving two hours every week to pondering questions seems like a whole lot of time. Joe got ripped off. And that means this episode goes into legal conversation and the woes of doing freelance work online.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/24-what-to-do-if-you-get-screwed/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/theoreticallogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

Thus, an explicit rating is required. In the end, we all need to learn how to work together on teams. Oh! And now it’s here. You’ve been warned. Also, Joe has some big news about the Guild.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/17-the-explicit-show/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/theoreticallogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

And it seems there are a lot of these. So picking a few is not as easy as it sounds.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/32-the-art-of-thinking-clearly-by-rolf-dobelli/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

Joe adds to the list of people he blames for missed goals. Josh is not losing weight. And they both struggle with being real on the internet.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/16-im-a-blue-person/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/theoreticallogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

Drew takes a deep dive into the strength of ‘Input’ and the helpful benefits of personality assessments. Also…Joe considers blacksmithing?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/5-a-beautiful-utopia-of-input/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/whimsthatworklogo.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

Joe rebranded the Guild and started pulling in content. And both of them digress on finances and chip cards.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/15-make-the-bad-guy-relatable/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/theoreticallogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-meta"><div class="meta-item">Jul 14, 2017</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag"  href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-icon"><a href="http://bookworm.fm/31/"><svg class="bookworm" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" version="1.1" x="0px" y="0px" viewBox="0 0 100 100" style="enable-background:new 0 0 100 100;" xml:space="preserve"><path d="M5.091,53.51C5.063,52.898,5,52.3,5,51.684C5,25.9,25.146,5,50,5s45,20.9,45,46.684  c0,0.616-0.068,1.215-0.088,1.826C93.977,28.583,74.26,8.656,50,8.656C25.739,8.656,6.022,28.583,5.091,53.51z M50,25.622  c15.164,0,27.527,12.291,28.425,27.788c0.034-0.6,0.088-1.191,0.088-1.796c0-16.338-12.764-29.579-28.513-29.579  S21.487,35.276,21.487,51.614c0,0.604,0.054,1.196,0.087,1.796C22.473,37.913,34.835,25.622,50,25.622z M50,34.274  c-5.158,0-9.343,4.342-9.343,9.692c0,5.35,4.186,9.691,9.343,9.691c5.156,0,9.342-4.342,9.342-9.691  C59.342,38.616,55.156,34.274,50,34.274z M50,54.467c-7.513,0-13.605,0.416-13.605,14.685C36.395,83.426,42.487,95,50,95  s13.605-11.574,13.605-25.849C63.605,54.883,57.513,54.467,50,54.467z"/></svg>  </a></div><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/31-the-power-of-a-positive-no-by-william-ury/"><h3>31: The Power of a Positive No by William Ury</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 14, 2017</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Saying No. It’s something neither Mike nor Joe enjoy doing but know they need to embrace. The question is whether or not they can bring themselves to do it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/31-the-power-of-a-positive-no-by-william-ury/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

And how does one go about marketing themselves without coming across as pushy? Also, they want to share more tidbits. So there’s more tidbits.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/14-what-comes-first/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/theoreticallogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

And Josh loves being frozen. And sometimes a bad experience for your child invokes a guttural and passionate response by the parent. Thus, Josh’s tirades.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/3-a-pair-of-tirades/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/theoreticallogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

Joe doesn’t get it. And yet they both explore the world of moving cheese together.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/20-who-moved-my-cheese-by-spencer-johnson/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

And if so, is it worth doing anything about? It’s a tough topic but Mike and Joe work their way through it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/19-the-shallows-by-nicholas-carr/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

To kick things off, we’ve reread a book we both rely on heavily in our lives, Getting Things Done by David Allen. This is the best discussion either of us have had about GTD in a long time.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/1-getting-things-done-by-david-allen/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>When you have a large amount of data available, it’s easy to be paralyzed in making a decision about how to analyze it. Oh, and I completely missed daylight savings.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/29/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Get-Started-and-Iterate.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

And that’s due to a lack of focus and alignment with my goals.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/28/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Why-Is-Focus-So-Hard.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

There are four ways I create new ideas. And I had a moment of insight about being content at a birthday party for our girls.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/25/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Creating-Ideas.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

And try not to spend too much time doing support for family. I’ve struggled with this in the past, but now I want to tie it to dollars. Also, I talk about why I think our babysitter is awesome.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/12/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/The-Higher-Horizons.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

I had a few different structures, but I think I ended with a simple setup that worked well for me before I outgrew it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/11/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Using-Evernote-for-GTD.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-meta"><div class="meta-item">Oct 20, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item">14:02</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag"  href="/tag/ads">ads</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-icon"><a href="/10/"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" version="1.1" x="0px" y="0px" viewBox="0 0 100 100" style="enable-background:new 0 0 100 100;" xml:space="preserve"><path fill="#f8d25b" d="M5.091,53.51C5.063,52.898,5,52.3,5,51.684C5,25.9,25.146,5,50,5s45,20.9,45,46.684  c0,0.616-0.068,1.215-0.088,1.826C93.977,28.583,74.26,8.656,50,8.656C25.739,8.656,6.022,28.583,5.091,53.51z M50,25.622  c15.164,0,27.527,12.291,28.425,27.788c0.034-0.6,0.088-1.191,0.088-1.796c0-16.338-12.764-29.579-28.513-29.579  S21.487,35.276,21.487,51.614c0,0.604,0.054,1.196,0.087,1.796C22.473,37.913,34.835,25.622,50,25.622z M50,34.274  c-5.158,0-9.343,4.342-9.343,9.692c0,5.35,4.186,9.691,9.343,9.691c5.156,0,9.342-4.342,9.342-9.691  C59.342,38.616,55.156,34.274,50,34.274z M50,54.467c-7.513,0-13.605,0.416-13.605,14.685C36.395,83.426,42.487,95,50,95  s13.605-11.574,13.605-25.849C63.605,54.883,57.513,54.467,50,54.467z"/></svg></a></div><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/10/"><h3>10: Why I Don't Use Ads</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 20, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/ads">ads</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’ve avoided ads in my creative work from the beginning. But there’s a lot of pressure to use them as a way to make an income. In this episode, I explain why I don’t plan to change.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/10/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Why-I-Dont-Use-Ads.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-meta"><div class="meta-item">Oct 13, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item">16:32</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag"  href="/tag/journaling">journaling</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag"  href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-icon"><a href="/9/"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" version="1.1" x="0px" y="0px" viewBox="0 0 100 100" style="enable-background:new 0 0 100 100;" xml:space="preserve"><path fill="#f8d25b" d="M5.091,53.51C5.063,52.898,5,52.3,5,51.684C5,25.9,25.146,5,50,5s45,20.9,45,46.684  c0,0.616-0.068,1.215-0.088,1.826C93.977,28.583,74.26,8.656,50,8.656C25.739,8.656,6.022,28.583,5.091,53.51z M50,25.622  c15.164,0,27.527,12.291,28.425,27.788c0.034-0.6,0.088-1.191,0.088-1.796c0-16.338-12.764-29.579-28.513-29.579  S21.487,35.276,21.487,51.614c0,0.604,0.054,1.196,0.087,1.796C22.473,37.913,34.835,25.622,50,25.622z M50,34.274  c-5.158,0-9.343,4.342-9.343,9.692c0,5.35,4.186,9.691,9.343,9.691c5.156,0,9.342-4.342,9.342-9.691  C59.342,38.616,55.156,34.274,50,34.274z M50,54.467c-7.513,0-13.605,0.416-13.605,14.685C36.395,83.426,42.487,95,50,95  s13.605-11.574,13.605-25.849C63.605,54.883,57.513,54.467,50,54.467z"/></svg></a></div><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/9/"><h3>9: Really? Journaling?</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 13, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/journaling">journaling</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I can’t believe I’ve started journaling every day. I’ve always equated journaling with writing in a diary, which is not for me. But the effects of not journaling caught me off-guard.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/9/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Really-Journaling.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>When you have a new project that you’re doing research on, you need a great way to grab and store that research. But you need to be intentional with getting started.
